subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 28th June 2019: Cautious trade in thin ranges ahead of G20
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP – 28th June 2019: Cautious trade in thin ranges ahead of G20

 

  • * SNAPSHOT: Equites up, Treasuries mixed, Dollar flat, Crude mixed.
  • * REAR VIEW: US core PCE in line with expectations. Canada GDP beat; EZ inflation in line, core measure slightly higher.
  • * NEXT WEEK: WEEKEND: G20 in Osaka. MON: JMMC and OPEC meeting, Japanese Tankan, Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI, EZ, UK, US Manufacturing PMIs, German Labour Market Report, US Construction Spending, ISM Manufacturing. TUE: RBA policy announcement, OPEC+ meeting, German Retail Sales, UK Construction PMI, EZ PMI, Canadian RBC Manufacturing PMI. WED: Riksbank and NBP policy announcements, Chinese Caixin Services PMI, Turkish CPI, EZ, UK, US Services PMIs, US Challenger Job Cuts, ADP Employment Change, Factory Orders, ISM non-Manufacturing, Canadian Trade Balance. THU: US Independence Day, Australian & Eurozone Retail Sales, Swiss CPI. FRI: German Factory Orders and Industrial Production, US and Canadian Labour Market Reports. Click here for full report. Our central bank weekly briefing can be accessed here.

 

* G20 PREVIEW: The meeting between Trump and Xi is expected to take place on Saturday at 0330BST, and comes in the context of heightened tensions between the two nations after the US accused China in May of backtracking on some of the legal matters within the trade agreement. Following this, Trump took the decision to raise tariffs on USD 200bln of Chinese imports to 25% from 10%, and threatened to also tariff the remaining USD 325bln of Chinese goods at a rate of 25%; Trump this week scaled back his threat on the remaining Chinese goods to a rate of 10% versus the touted level in May of 25%. In response, China set import tariffs against over 5000 US products (USD 60bln) at rates ranging from 5% to 25%, thus ending the truce agreed at the November G20 summit. Since the tariff hikes, very little, if any, progress has been made between the two nations and thus the future path of negotiations may hinge on the weekend meeting. Expectations for a major breakthrough are relatively limited with US Commerce Secretary Ross recently remarking that striking a ‘definitive deal’ on a trade agreement that will amount to thousands of pages on the side-lines of a meeting would be highly unlikely. Instead, investors are looking at whether the two leaders can agree to a ceasefire, which will allow respective teams to iron out a deal. These expectations were underscored by an SCMP article indicating that such an agreement was already in place, according to sources; something which was later rebutted by China. Even if China and US are able to enforce a truce, Capital Economics questions the longevity of any such agreement given the demands the US is placing on China to change it industrial policy and alleged IP theft, something which China thus far has refused to do. The gulf in demands between the two parties was highlighted by a WSJ piece on Thursday, which revealed China’s three demands for the US in order to settle the trade dispute: 1) Lift ban on Huawei, 2) Remove punitive tariffs, 3) Drop efforts to get China to increase purchases of US exports; all of which are likely to be met with a frosty response by the US administration. Therefore, any optimism surrounding a trade truce could prove to be short-lived and as such, Capital Economics “think it more likely than not that 25% tariffs will be applied to all Chinese imports by early next year and that China will retaliate with tariffs and non-tariff measures”. Such a move could deal a further blow to markets as the trade overhang continues to hamper global growth prospects and pose further concerns for central bankers, some of which, have limited room to the downside to combat such negative market forces. Additionally, further speculation will continue to mount over whether or not USD/CNY will breach 7.00 to the upside, a move which could trigger capital outflows of China and draw the ire of the White House amid accusations of currency manipulation.

* OPEC: OPEC+ is widely expected to rollover the existing 1.2mln BPD supply curb pact at the meetings in Vienna next week; a bullish outcome would be the announcement of deeper than existing cuts, and a bearish being a reduction/conclusion of cuts. The G20 summit is a tail risk due to the possibility, albeit slim, of a large shift in trade tensions moving demand expectations in either direction. Goldman Sachs highlights the uncertainty in the oil market, “driven by both an uncertain macro outlook and debatable Iran/Venezuela/US production,” which the bank believes will cause the group to walk the path of least resistance (a rollover with no change to current quotas). In regard to individual members, Saudi Arabia, the largest producer in OPEC, has expressed its preference for the extensions leading up to the event, RBC’s analysts expect it to announce at the meeting its willingness to “swing both ways” to balance the market, and given the country’s need for higher fiscal revenues, analysts expect it to lean towards further cuts rather than the opposite, but the risk of upsetting US President Trump with too high oil prices will limit excessive cuts. The wildcard to the meeting is external member Russia, where comments from officials have been less decisive on committing to the extension. Russian oil corporates have been more outright in their comments, expressing opposition to the extension, too. RBC suggests that ultimately Russia will not dissent, mainly due to President Putin beginning to face deteriorating economic conditions domestically, where an upset with OPEC allies would jeopardise his power in the cartel in addition to the benefits Russia has gained from new, wide-ranging trade deals.

* IRAN: US Special Representative on Iran Hook said that Iran has rejected diplomacy too many times and that sanctions will be imposed on any illicit purchase of Iranian oil. Hook went on, saying If the US doesn’t prevent Iran from laying deep roots in Yemen, Iran will be in a position to close the Strait of Hormuz. In regard to Washington’s ever growing economic grip on Iran, Hook said the US is on track to deny Iran USD 50bln in oil revenue alone, and will intensify sanctions on Iran until it decides to be a normal state. Elsewhere, an Iranian Foreign Ministry Spokesman said Iran's next move regarding the Nuclear deal depends on the EU's practical measures (Iran had previously said it requires the EU to continue providing revenue for oil), and following ongoing nuclear deal talks, an Iranian Envoy said the meeting was a step forwards, but it was not enough to change Tehran's stance on the deal's limit, indicating it would continue growing its stocks of enriched uranium. Meanwhile, an EU Statement says Iran nuclear deal remains key element of global nuclear non-proliferation, special EU channel to allow trad with Iran and circumvent US sanctions is now operational

* WTI FUTURES (Q9) SETTLES USD 0.96 LOWER AT USD 58.47; BRENT (Q9, EXPIRES) SETTLES UNCHANGED AT USD 66.55: The energy complex has been consolidating in a narrow range to end the week ahead of the G20 summit and OPEC+ meeting next week. Citi’s energy analysts note how Friday has been a day of moderate-volume book squaring in anticipation of the events and end of month/quarter/H1 flows, in addition,  “August Brent futures, July heating oil, and July RBOB gasoline futures all expire today, adding a more routine element of book squaring to the trade.” Ahead of the Vienna OPEC+ meeting the WSJ reported that OPEC are set to extend the supply cuts in H2, with some set to argue for deeper cuts, but key-member Saudi is unlikely to back such a move. Additionally, with eyes on Russia given its previous scepticism to the extensions, Russian Energy Minister Novak said the Kremlin has consolidated the position with Russian oil companies concerning the cuts, who previously were opposed to them, but did not specify what they agreed; however, there is wide consensus that Russia will, more likely than not, not dissent from OPEC. The Baker Hughes US rig count for the latest week recorded oil rigs +4 at 793, nat gas rigs -4 at 173, leaving total rigs unchanged at 967. In pre-settlement trade, the EU said its vehicle to circumvent US sanctions was ready to go, leading to downside for WTI, with traders rationalising that the vehicle to allow the buying of Iranian crude would lessen demand for US WTI.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLED 1 TICKS HIGHER AT 127-31: Anticipation around the meeting between President Trump and Xi overnight has kept trading cautious on Friday, which was also the last trading day before month/quarter/H1 end. The Treasury curve was mixed, but yields only deviated by around +/- 1bps at settlement, with major curve spreads little changed.

* S&P 500 0.6% AT 2941, NASDAQ-100 0.2% AT 7671, DOW JONES 0.3% AT 26596. SECTORS: S&P 500 Consumer Discretionary  0.2%, S&P 500 Consumer Staples 0.1%, S&P 500 Energy  1.2%, S&P 500 Financials  1.3%, S&P 500 Health Care  0.4%, S&P 500 Industrials  1%, S&P 500 Information Technology  0.1%, S&P 500 Materials  0.8%, S&P 500 Telecommunication Services  0.8%, S&P 500 Utilities  0.5%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Financials were outperforming on Friday following all the major US banks having their capital spending plans approved by the Fed on the back of successful stress tests. Apple (AAPL) weighed on indices after its Chief Designer announced his departure. Nike (NKE) drifted lower on the back of its earnings, where it beat on revenue but missed on EPS, in addition to some lacklustre revenue guidance for the next quarter. Constellation Brands (STZ) had a star reaching earnings report, topping both EPS and revenue estimates as well as guidance expectations. Raytheon (RTN) underperformed as investor Daniel Loeb joined with Bill Ackman to oppose the United Technologies (UTX) merger. Proctor & Gamble (PG) opened higher on an upgrade at Goldman, whilst Biogen (BIIB) opened lower with gratitude to a downgrade at Piper Jaffray.

* WEEKLY FX WRAP - DXY: The broad Dollar and Index kicked the week off holding onto most of last week’s Fed-induced losses. DXY is poised to end the EU session little changed from Sunday’s open and in a relatively narrow range, having visited a weekly low of 95.84 and a high of 96.39. The index rebounded from post-FOMC lows amid a tag-team of Fed Chair Powell and dissenter Bullard who tempered expectations for a 50bps cut as it seems too aggressive. The upside however abated as many bank models pointed to USD selling heading into month/quarter/HY end whilst G20 expectation remain for a calming of tensions (for now) between US and China. In terms of key tech levels heading into the G20, the DXY sees its 200 WMA to the downside at 95.97 whilst to the upside, the 50 WMA resides at 96.37.

* EUR, GBP: The Single Currency is set to end the EU week with marginal gains, albeit sub-1.14 having traded in a 1.1344-1.1412 weekly band vs the Dollar. EUR/USD mostly traded at the whim of the Buck tested its 200 DMA (1.1344) to the downside in wake of Powell and Bullard’s rate cut expectation tempering. The EUR also failed to materialise on gains seen following the encouraging German prelim inflation data, partially due to restricting hefty option expiries on the day. Elsewhere, the Pound is poised to end the session on the backfoot amid Brexit/political uncertainty coupled with month-end EUR/GBP demand. Cable looks to close EU trade just above the 1.2700 level after little reaction to in-line GDP and having traded within a 1.2661-2783 band.

* AUD, NZD, CAD: A strong weekly performance by the risk currencies vs the Buck and all poised to end the EU week on a firmer footing. Firstly, the Aussie kicked the week off with gains amid comments from RBA Governor Lowe took a less dovish stance and noted that rate cuts will be less effective if other Central Banks are also in easing mode and has since gained further ground against the Dollar, partly aided by an improvement in China industrial profits. The AUD is now gearing up for the G20 summit to which it’ll be one of the more sensitive G10s given its exposure to China. Furthermore, next week sees the latest RBA rate decision with analysts split on whether the CB will cut or hold, whilst money markets are pricing an 80% chance of a June cut to 1.00%. The Kiwi is set to notch a fifth day of gains, aided partly by the RBNZ (to recap, an easing bias was maintained but also noted two contradictory factors were highlighted alongside subdued domestic growth and downside risks to inflation and employment targets relative to the previous meeting in May), but a bulk of the momentum was seen earlier in the week amid the release of trade balance metrics which topped expectations. NZD/USD set to close the EU session above its 200 DMA (0.6709) having already breached its 100 DMA/50WMA (0.6696/0.6699). Finally, the CAD, also on the front-foot vs the USD as USD/CAD is set to the end week near the bottom of a 1.3068-3261 band, partially aided by the rebound in oil whilst the above forecast GDP figures also provided the Loonie some impetus to gain more ground against the Greenback.

* JPY, CHF: The safe haven FX look to end the week mixed with the Yen closer to the top of a weekly 106.78-108.16, albeit the bulk of the action was inspired by the rebound in the Buck post-Powell/Bullard before a relatively tentative end to the trading week ahead of the G20 summit. Meanwhile, the Franc is set to close the session largely unchanged for the week and at the middle of a 0.9700-9810 range.

Bank of Canada Q2 Business Outlook Survey: Slight improvement in business sentiment; hiring and investment sentiment remain healthy
content:
• Following some softness in past sales, businesses expect an increase in sales growth in the next 12 months, backed by healthy domestic and foreign demand
  • Weakness tied to the Western Canadian oil industry and global trade headwinds continue to hold back future sales.
  • Intentions to increase investment spending and to hire are positive in most regions and sectors.
  • After falling in the last survey, the indicator of capacity pressures recovered somewhat. Reports of labour shortages increased from a low level but are not widespread.
  • Input price growth is expected to slow slightly as several firms anticipate the pressures on input prices from tariffs will fade over the next 12 months. Output price growth is expected to accelerate modestly as more firms see favourable conditions for passing on various cost increases to customers. Inflation expectations are unchanged. A majority of firms anticipate inflation will be in the lower half of the Bank of Canada’s inflation-control range.
  • Firms reported a marginal net easing in credit conditions over the past three months.
  • The Business Outlook Survey indicator edged up to its historical average, consistent with a slight improvement in business sentiment.
  • Full report
reaction_details: • In an immediate reaction to the business sentiment showing slight improvement, USD/CAD declined 20 pips from 1.3095 to 1.3075 before stabilising around 1.3085

DOW

  • Apple (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) Chief Design Officer Jony Ive, which some analysts have suggested is the tech giant’s second most important person, is to depart in order to establish his own design co, which Apple will become a client of.
  • Boeing (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) sees September as the completion date for the 737 MAX jet software update fix, where the FAA could sign off by late-September.
  • Exxon Mobil (XOM) (Energy/Oil, Gas & Consumable Fuels) and Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA LN, RDS.A) (Energy/Oil, Gas & Consumable Fuels) are looking at the possibility of re-entering Somalia’s upstream sector amid civil unrest in the country.
  • Nike (NKE) (Consumer Discretionary/Textiles, Apparel & Luxury Goods) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 0.62 vs. Exp. USD 0.66, Rev. 10.2bln vs. Exp. 10.16bln. North America revenue rises 7% Y/Y (ex. FX charges), EMEA rises 9%, China rises 22%, APAC rises 9%. Inventory stood at 5.7bln USD, +7% Y/Y. Affirmed FY20 revenue growth view of high single digit range; sees Q1 revenue in-line to slightly above Q4 revenue (exp. 10.64bln).
  • Pfizer (PFE) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) has appointed formed FDA Commissioner Scott Gottlieb to its Board of Directors. Separately, the pharma giant has received FDA approval for one of its cancer drugs, Zirabev, for treatment of five types of cancers.
  • Proctor & Gamble (PG) (Consumer Staples/Household Products) has been upgraded to Buy from Neutral by Goldman analyst Jason English, who has raised his PT to USD 125 from USD 114 citing room for relative outperformance and sustained organic strength.
  • Walmart’s (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Food & Staples Retailing) Indian unit, Flipkart, plans to replace 40% of its existing delivery fleet with electric vehicles by March 2020.

NASDAQ 100

  • Amgen (AMGN) (Health Care/Biotechnology), alongside UCB, have announced they have received a negative opinion on their osteoporosis candidate Evenity by the European Medicines Agency’s Committee for Medicinal Products for Human Use.
  • Baidu (BIDU) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) – Toyota Motors (TM) plans to join the Baidu lead self-driving platform, Apollo, according to Nikkei Asian Review.
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) said that the combustion of one of its vehicles in Shanghai was due to one faulty battery module rather than a systematic fault.

S&P 500

  • Accenture (ACN) (Information Technology/IT Services) has entered a JV with Mujin in AI and robotics for the logistics industry.
  • Constellation Brands Inc (STZ) (Consumer Staples/Beverages) Q1 19 (USD): EPS 2.21 (Exp. 2.08), Revenue 2.097bln (exp. 2.06bln). Raises FY20 EPS view to 8.65-8.95 (from 8.50-8.80).
  • Fortinet (FTNT) (Information Technology/Software) has been upgraded to Overweight from Neutral by JPMorgan analyst Sterling Auty, where he believes the co. is pursuing the right strategy following a 20% price decline from its YTD highs.
  • Huntington Bancshares (HBAN) (Financials/Banks) has announced proposed capital actions for 2019, which include a 7% increase in the quarterly dividend to USD 0.15/shr in Q3, and a USD 513mln share repurchase programme.
  • Sempra Energy (SRE) (Utilities/Multi-Utilities) is having penalties against it being mulled by Californian regulators due to a four-month gas leak in 2015 by its subsidiary SoCalGas.

  • Yandex (YNDX) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) – The Russian tech co. has said there has been no data compromises following reports of western intelligence agencies spying on user accounts at the end of 2018.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 28th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European Equities are just into positive territory [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.3%], with the Fed having approved all 18 banks capital plans in their Comprehensive Capital Analysis Review
  • US President Trump says he will be meeting with Chinese President Xi tomorrow and thinks the meeting will be productive at a minimum; it will ultimately work out, though he did not promise a 6-month tariff reprieve
  • FX and Fixed remain tentative and rangebound ahead of the weekend’s G20 and as month/quarter & half year end occurs
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Core PCE, Chicago PMI & University of Michigan Sentiment, Canadian GDP, G20 Meeting, and Fed’s Daly

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were subdued amid book squaring heading into the end of H1 and ahead of the upcoming Trump-Xi meeting at the G20. ASX 200 (-0.7%) was led lower by mining names with BHP pressured as it is expected to pay AUD 250mln as settlement in the royalty dispute with Western Australia, although downside for the broader market was limited by outperformance in tech and financials, while Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) also suffered losses in the commodity-related sectors and with exporters weighed by detrimental flows into the currency. Hang Seng (-0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) weakened amid continued PBoC inaction and as trade uncertainty remained rife heading into the US-China showdown at the G20. Finally, 10yr JGBs tracked the upside in their US counterparts with prices lifted by safe-haven flows and amid the BoJ presence in the market for JPY 720bln of government bonds in the belly to super-long end. 

PBoC skipped open market operations and were net neutral for the week vs. Prev. CNY 285bln injection last week. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8747 (Prev. 6.8778)

US President Trump said he and India PM Modi will have very big trade deals to announce, while India PM Modi commented that wants to discuss Iran, 5G, as well bilateral and defense relations with US President Trump. (Newswires)

Japanese PM Abe said tensions over trade and geopolitical risks are increasing, while he added that trade restriction measures do not benefit any country and that any trade steps should be in line with WTO rules. (Newswires)

BoJ Summary of Opinions from June 19th-20th Meeting stated it is necessary to persistently continue with the current powerful monetary easing as the momentum toward 2% inflation is maintained. The summary added that the BoJ needs to consider measures that enhance sustainability of easing and that all policy measures including adjustments in short- and long-term interest rates, an acceleration in the pace of expansion in the monetary base, and an increase in the amount of assets to be purchased should be deliberated when considering additional easing. (Newswires)

Chinese Global Times Editor says from senior officials to ordinary people are increasingly believing since the trade war that hurts the economy can't persist under US political system, as long as China insists, the US will back down eventually. (Twitter)

Chinese Foreign Minister are hopeful that the US and China can meet halfway and ensure the meeting is a success. (Newswires) 

US

US President Trump says he will be meeting with Chinese President Xi tomorrow and thinks the meeting will be productive at a minimum, ultimately it will work out, added that he did not promise President Xi a 6-month reprieve of tariffs. (Newswires)

Japan Economy Minister Motegi says that as early as next month the US and Japan are to hold working-level trade talks; which will be at accelerating progress on Japan-US trade discussions. (Newswires)

Fed approved all 18 banks capital plans in its Comprehensive Capital Analysis Review, although Credit Suisse received conditional approval and must address weaknesses. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said there is absolutely no time pressure on Iran issue and that he thinks it will work out but added 'if it doesn't you will hear about it'. (Newswires)

US President Trump says a lot of positive things will come out of his "very very good relationship" with Russian President Putin. (Newswires)

US Trade Representative Lighthizer, Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Chinese Vice Premier Lui are meeting to discuss trade war, according to sources. (Newswires)

EU's Tusk said need to keep communication channels open with Iran and that the EU is committed to the deal as long as Iran is committed to uphold it. Furthermore, EU’s Tusk strongly urges Iran to fully implement all commitments and stated that the EU takes any breach seriously. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM candidate Boris Johnson is preparing an emergency budget for no-deal which includes aggressive tax cuts and overhaul of stamp duty if he becomes PM, while there were separate reports that Boris Johnson's allies stated he offered Home Secretary Javid the role of Chancellor of the Exchequer. (The Times/Newswires)

UK GDP YY (Q1) 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 1.8%)

- UK GDP QQ (Q1) 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.5%)

EU HICP Flash YY (Jun) 1.2% vs. Exp. 1.2% (Prev. 1.2%)

- EU HICP-X F&E Flash YY (Jun) 1.2% vs. Exp. 1.0% (Prev. 1.0%)

- EU HICP-X Food, Energy, Alcohol & Tobacco Flash YY (Jun) 1.10% vs. Exp. 1.00% (Prev. 0.80%)

EQUITIES

Major European indices are just into positive territory after a tentative and mixed/flat open [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.3%] as the G20 summit gets underway and markets move into month, quarter and half end. Within the bourses the SMI (-0.2%) is the modest underperformer as we approach the Sunday expiry of temporary measures introduced by the EU which allow Swiss Co’s to be traded on EU exchanges; most recently the Swiss Government stated they will block trading of Swiss shares in the EU following the Commission stating they do not see reason to extend the measures beyond June. In terms of this morning notable movers, significantly outperforming at the top of the Stoxx 600 are Merlin Entertainment (+14.0%) after reports that the Co. had received a GBP 6bln offer from the Lego Family, Blackstone & a Canadian fund. On the back of yesterday’s Fed stress tests where all banks capital plans were approved Deutsche Bank (+3.7%) are the outperforming financial name; however, Credit Suisse (-1.0%) are lagging their peers after receiving only conditional approval and being the Co. must now address the relevant weaknesses.

Fed approved all 18 banks capital plans in its Comprehensive Capital Analysis Review, although Credit Suisse (CSGN SW) received conditional approval and must address weaknesses. (Newswires)

Tesla (TSLA) finds no systematic flaws in vehicles following investigation into vehicle fire in Shanghai. (Newswires)

FX

DXY, CNH - The broad Dollar and Index remain in a relatively confined 96.05-25 range as markets gear up for tomorrow’s US-Sino showdown. US President Trump said that he believes the meeting with his Chinese counterpart (at 0330BST tomorrow) will be “productive at minimum”. The comments somewhat reaffirmed market expectations for a restart in talks, but no breakthrough. The index currently hovers closer to the bottom of the intraday range ahead of the psychological 96.00 and its 200 WMA at 95.97, while to the upside, technicians will be eyeing resistance at 96.37 (50 WMA). Meanwhile, US Core PCE and comments from Fed’s Daly are unlikely to sway the Buck ahead of the weekend’s risk event. In a similar vein, CNH is caged within a tight 6.86-88 range vs Greenback but is ultimately flat, having briefly dipped below its 50 DMA at 6.8675.

EUR, GBP, NZD, AUD, JPY, CHF - All largely benefitting from a marginally softer USD, albeit the EUR also feels tailwind from touted month-end EUR/GBP buying, which aided the pair climb to levels last seen in January. EUR was little moved by the release of overall encouraging inflation data in which the core and super-core figures topped estimates while the headline matched expectations. EUR/USD remains near the top of a 1.1360-90 intraday band with around 1bln in options scattered around strikes 1.1375-85. Meanwhile, the GBP is benefiting slightly less from a softer USD amid the aforementioned EUR/GBP buying as Cable remains within a tight band under 1.2700. Elsewhere the AUD and NZD have similarly jumped on the back of a softer Buck and over close to HODs of 0.7017 and 0.6710 respectively, albeit off best levels. Finally, the safe heaven FX follow suit from the tentative tone in the FX market, although positioning before the end of the trading day may sway the currencies. USD/JPY hovers just above the near the bottom of a 107.57-83 range with 2.1bln in options expiring at 107.50 at today’s NY cut.

NOK, SEK - The Swedish Crown has pared back recent losses vs. the EUR after dismal retail sales extended the pair’s intraday upper bound to 10.5850, albeit the SEK has since pared back those losses and trades flat on the day thus far. Meanwhile, the NOK was little fazed by the regional unemployment figures and fares slightly worse but ultimately on the back of softer energy prices.

FIXED INCOME

A tentative and little changed end to the week for Core bonds thus far, as markets are afflicted by compounding month, quarter and half year end effects as well as the ever-looming Trump-Xi G20 meeting finally upon us. No significant updates on the trade rhetoric since yesterdays WSJ piece on the 3 Chinese preconditions, Trump and Xi are currently scheduled to hold talks at 03:30 BST on Saturday. A relatively busy session thus far with several notable releases on the data slate, though none have been sufficient in magnitude/print to divert bonds from their current holding pattern. Bunds are at the centre of a slim 30 tick range for the day at 172.58, and largely unreactive to the firmer German import data and EZ Core CPI, the session low of 172.46 printed around the cash equity open and shortly after the firmer French Prelim CPI (1.4% vs. Exp. 1.1%). Elsewhere, and having stayed within an even narrower range than their EU counterparts, Gilts are in the middle of the days range and were unsurprisingly unreactive to the unrevised GDP figure. In a continuation of the trend from their European peers USTs are also rangebound at 127-24+, which is just shy of their opening print. Looking ahead the data slate stateside may generate some inspiration, with the Core PCE, University of Michigan and Chicago PMI figures likely to be closely watched for any further data-input on the proability and magnitude of upcoming Fed cuts.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are cautious ahead talks between US President Trump and his Chinese counterpart. The benchmarks found supports USD 59/bbl and USD 66/bbl respectively but remain subdued on the day. Post-G20, the energy market will be looking forward to the delayed OPEC+ meeting in which the oil producers are expected to roll over the output curbs but still seem split on potential revisions to the pact. Russia still remains the unknown, despite Energy Minister Novak stating that consensus will be found in July, however “the potential downside risk in the market in the event of a no deal will likely be enough to persuade Russia to continue” ING says. Back to G20, analysts remind us that talks between Russian President Putin and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman will also be monitored as it may influence the cartel’s decision. Elsewhere, gold is marginally firmer on the day as a function of a weaker Dollar. In light of the recent gold rally, UBS has raised its 3-month gold forecast to USD 1430/oz from USD 1380/oz. Meanwhile, Copper remains above the USD 2.7/lb as the softer USD outweighs the supply resumptions from the end of strikes at the Coldeco Chuquicamata mine. The workers, after 14 days, have accepted the latest offer and miners returned to work today.

Codelco's Chuquicamata Mine workers unions are said to accept pay offer ending a 2-week strike. (Newswires)

Russian Energy Minister Novak says they have consolidated the position with Russian oil companies concerning future global oil output deals., Tass. (Newswires)

subject: US Special Representative on Iran Hook says Iran has rejected diplomacy too many times, adding that sanctions will be imposed on any illicit purchase of Iranian oil
content:
• If we do not prevent Iran from laying deep roots in Yemen, Iran will be in a position to close the Strait of Hormuz
  • We are on track to deny Iran USD 50bln in oil revenue alone
  • We will intensify sanction on Iran until it decided to be a normal state

US President Trump said that he believes the meeting with his Chinese counterpart (at 0330BST tomorrow) will be “productive at minimum”. The comments somewhat reaffirmed market expectations for a restart in talks, but no breakthrough. The index currently hovers closer to the bottom of the intraday range ahead of the psychological 96.00 and its 200 WMA at 95.97, while to the upside, technicians will be eyeing resistance at 96.37 (50 WMA). Meanwhile, US Core PCE and comments from Fed’s Daly are unlikely to sway the Buck ahead of the weekend’s risk event. In a similar vein, CNH is caged within a tight 6.86-88 range vs Greenback but is ultimately flat, having briefly dipped below its 50 DMA at 6.8675.

 

EUR, GBP, NZD, AUD, JPY, CHF

All largely firmer from a marginally softer USD, albeit the EUR also feels tailwind from touted month-end EUR/GBP buying, which aided the pair climb to levels last seen in January. EUR was little moved by the release of overall encouraging inflation data in which the core and super-core figures topped estimates while the headline matched expectations. EUR/USD remains near the top of a 1.1360-90 intraday band with around 1bln in options scattered around strikes 1.1375-85. Meanwhile, the GBP is benefiting slightly less from a softer USD amid the aforementioned EUR/GBP buying as Cable remains within a tight band under 1.2700. Elsewhere the AUD and NZD have similarly jumped on the back of a softer Buck and over close to HODs of 0.7017 and 0.6710 respectively, albeit off best levels. Finally, the safe heaven FX follow suit from the tentative tone in the FX market, although positioning before the end of the trading day may sway the currencies. USD/JPY hovers just above the near the bottom of a 107.57-83 range with 2.1bln in options expiring at 107.50 at today’s NY cut. 

 

NOK, SEK 

The Swedish Crown has pared back recent losses vs. the EUR after dismal retail sales extended the pair’s intraday upper bound to 10.5850, albeit the SEK has since pared back those losses and trades flat on the day thus far. Meanwhile, the NOK was little fazed by the regional unemployment figures and fares slightly worse but ultimately on the back of softer energy prices.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

28th June 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were subdued amid book squaring heading into the end of H1 and after the firm rebound in June, with participants also tentative as focus remained on the upcoming Trump-Xi meeting at the G20. ASX 200 (-0.5%) was led lower by mining names with BHP pressured as it is expected to pay AUD 250mln as settlement in the royalty dispute with Western Australia, although downside for the broader market was limited by outperformance in tech and financials, while Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) also suffered losses in the commodity-related sectors and with exporters weighed by detrimental flows into the currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.9%) weakened amid continued PBoC inaction and as trade uncertainty remained rife heading into the US-China showdown at the G20. Recent reports suggested Chinese President Xi intends to present a set of terms to settle the trade dispute and that Beijing insists the US remove the Huawei ban, lift all punitive tariffs and drop efforts to get China to buy even more US exports, which is unlikely to bode well with the US side and reduces the chances of a breakthrough in talks.

Glencore (GLEN LN) – Co. has confirmed the deaths of at least 19 illegal miners, with possible further unconfirmed fatalities at the open-pit mine owned by the Co.’s subsidiary. Co. says production at the mine was not affected by the incident. (Newswires)

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 28th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • ·        Asian equity markets were subdued amid book squaring heading into the end of H1 and ahead of the upcoming Trump-Xi meeting at the G20

·        FX price action was uneventful across the board with the DXY little changed on the session as its major counterparts sat rangebound

·        UK PM candidate Boris Johnson is reportedly preparing an emergency budget for no-deal

·        Fed approved all 18 banks capital plans in its Comprehensive Capital Analysis Review

·        Looking ahead, highlights include UK GfK, German Import Prices, UK GDP, EZ CPI, US Core PCE, Chicago PMI & University of Michigan Sentiment, Canadian GDP, G20 Meeting, ECB’s Lautenschlager and Fed’s Daly

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were subdued amid book squaring heading into the end of H1 and ahead of the upcoming Trump-Xi meeting at the G20. ASX 200 (-0.5%) was led lower by mining names with BHP pressured as it is expected to pay AUD 250mln as settlement in the royalty dispute with Western Australia, although downside for the broader market was limited by outperformance in tech and financials, while Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) also suffered losses in the commodity-related sectors and with exporters weighed by detrimental flows into the currency. Hang Seng (-0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.9%) weakened amid continued PBoC inaction and as trade uncertainty remained rife heading into the US-China showdown at the G20. Finally, 10yr JGBs tracked the upside in their US counterparts with prices lifted by safe-haven flows and amid the BoJ presence in the market for JPY 720bln of government bonds in the belly to super-long end. 

PBoC skipped open market operations and were net neutral for the week vs. Prev. CNY 285bln injection last week. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8747 (Prev. 6.8778)

 

US President Trump said he and India PM Modi will have very big trade deals to announce, while India PM Modi commented that wants to discuss Iran, 5G, as well bilateral and defense relations with US President Trump. (Newswires)

 

Japanese PM Abe said tensions over trade and geopolitical risks are increasing, while he added that trade restriction measures do not benefit any country and that any trade steps should be in line with WTO rules. (Newswires)

 

BoJ Summary of Opinions from June 19th-20th Meeting stated it is necessary to persistently continue with the current powerful monetary easing as the momentum toward 2% inflation is maintained. The summary added that the BoJ needs to consider measures that enhance sustainability of easing and that all policy measures including adjustments in short- and long-term interest rates, an acceleration in the pace of expansion in the monetary base, and an increase in the amount of assets to be purchased should be deliberated when considering additional easing. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM candidate Boris Johnson is preparing an emergency budget for no-deal which includes aggressive tax cuts and overhaul of stamp duty if he becomes PM, while there were separate reports that Boris Johnson's allies stated he offered Home Secretary Javid the role of Chancellor of the Exchequer. (The Times/Newswires)

UK GfK Consumer Confidence (Jun) -13 vs. Exp. -11.0 (Prev. -10.0). (Newswires) UK Lloyds Business Barometer (Jun) 13 (Prev. 10)

FX

Price action was uneventful across the board with the DXY little changed on the session as its major counterparts sat rangebound with EUR/USD steady after support around its 200DMA held in yesterday’s session, while GBP/USD was lacklustre following a recent failed attempt to reclaim 1.2700. Elsewhere, the risk averse tone pressured USD/JPY and spurred a mild pullback for antipodeans which briefly compromised the 0.7000 and 0.6700 levels for AUD/USD and NZD/USD respectively, while the most action came from outside G10 currencies in which USD/HKD slipped below 7.8100 and USD/INR tripped through stops at 69.00 to the downside with the quote currency encouraged after US President Trump’s suggested that very large trade deals with India will be announced. 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed overnight in which WTI crude futures were slightly softer as it navigated between near-term support and resistance levels at USD 59.00/bbl and USD59.50/bbl levels respectively, with participants tentative heading into the G20 and OPEC meeting early next week. Elsewhere, gold strengthened in a continued rebound from support at the USD 1400/oz level with the precious metal underpinned by safe haven demand and is on track for its biggest monthly gain since 2016, while copper was relatively kept flat as the tailwinds from the fresh record highs in Dalian iron ore was somewhat offset by the risk averse tone.

Russian President Putin said the oil output cut deal has been a positive for stabilising markets, which producers and consumers want. Russian President Putin said BRICS should work to reduce volatility on global energy markets, while he added we should work on bringing stability to Syria and that BRICS should take a more active role on the Syria issue. (FT/Newswires)

Codelco's Chuquicamata Mine workers unions are said to accept pay offer ending a 2-week strike. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

 

US President Trump said there is absolutely no time pressure on Iran issue and that he thinks it will work out but added 'if it doesn't you will hear about it'. (Newswires)

Iranian official said the US wants talks but we are at an economic war and there needs to be a ceasefire for talks to begin. The official added that the first stage would be the allowance of Iran to sell its own oil and receive the money from it, while he suggested that export levels would need to return to levels before the US sanctions were re-imposed and commented that Europeans should either buy Iranian oil or give its money to us. (Newswires)

EU's Tusk said need to keep communication channels open with Iran and that the EU is committed to the deal as long as Iran is committed to uphold it. Furthermore, EU’s Tusk strongly urges Iran to fully implement all commitments and stated that the EU takes any breach seriously. (Newswires)

 

US

 

Yields fell by around 4bps across the curve on Thursday, ahead of Friday’s G20 meeting, with major curve spreads undergoing modest narrowing of around 1bps. Weak ESI out of the Eurozone provided some impetus to the FI complex, and gains extended into the US open, after more woes at Boeing saw equity futures come under pressure. A WSJ article which was negative on trade developments allowed the upside to continue. Pending home sales data and hawkish remarks from Kudlow on trade allowed the bulls to continue to reign. The US 7-year auction stopped through the screens by 0.2bps, and cover improved though remained beneath the six auction average. The direct bid was strong, and the indirect bid subsequently eased a touch. The complex was near highs at settlement. US T-note futures settled 11 ticks higher at 127-30.

Fed's Daly (Non-Voter, Dove) said it is too early to know whether the Fed should cut rates, or by how much in July. (Newswires)

Fed approved all 18 banks capital plans in its Comprehensive Capital Analysis Review, although Credit Suisse received conditional approval and must address weaknesses. (Newswires)

S&P affirmed US at AA+; Outlook Stable, while it commented that ratings are constrained by high general government debt and fiscal deficits, as well as relatively short-term policymaking. (Newswires)

content:

Luk Fook Holdings (590 HK) - Co. FY19 net HKD 1.49bln vs. Prev. HKD 1.37bln Y/Y, rev. HKD 15.86bln vs. Prev. HKD 14.57bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Shipbuilders - State-Owned China Shipbuilding Industry Corp is said to sign CNY 14.3bln. (Xinhua)

Trade

US President Trump could agree to delay new tariffs on China but it is still unknown what Trump is going to do and could delay tariffs and change his mind, according to reports citing a senior White House Official. There were also comments from US NEC Director Kudlow that there are no preconditions in trade talks with China, while he added that the US may move ahead with additional tariffs on Chinese products and nothing was agreed upon before the Trump-Xi meeting. (Politico/Fox News)

Senior US official said President Trump's decision on whether to impose more tariffs on Chinese goods is contingent on the Xi meeting, with nothing agreed ahead of time and that it is unlikely the US would agree to lift the Huawei restrictions. Furthermore, there were reports that the US will not give China a 'balanced' trade deal due to past transgressions made by China, although a truce is possible even if there is no agreement on the issues, while the sources added that it is not clear how long a truce would last as President Trump likes deadline pressure and USTR Lighthizer doesn't. (Newswires/CNBC)

Chinese President Xi is intending on presenting US President Trump with a set of terms that the US needs to meet before Beijing will be prepared to settle the trade dispute, according to reports citing a Chinese Official. Beijing is said to be insisting that the US remove its ban on tech sales to Huawei, lift all punitive tariffs and drop efforts to get China to buy even more US exports. However, reports noted that despite these preconditions, President Xi is not anticipated to undertake a confrontational stance with US President Trump and will outline his visions as to the optimal bilateral relations between the two countries. (Newswires)

China's MOFCOM urged the US to immediately cancel sanctions on Chinese firms including Huawei and stated that it opposes US abuse of export control, while it is also to consider placing firms on an unreliable list if they implement discriminatory measures on Chinese entities and also firms that threaten the national security of China. In related news, China MOFCOM spokesman Geng stated they are not aware of the SCMP report regarding a tentative trade deal. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor tweeted that 2-days prior to Trump-Xi meeting, US President Trump claims to have a Plan B and has threatened new tariffs which is a very unfriendly move and will for sure have a negative impact. (Twitter)

 

Other News 

PBoC reiterated that the CNY will be kept reasonably stable and that it will not resort to flood-like stimulus, while it also repeated that monetary policy should neither be too tight nor too loose and that the Chinese economy faces increasing external uncertainties. (Newswires)
